title: Connect and Redirect
summary: First connect with your child emotionally, then guide their behavior logically.

details.content: Children in distress are often dominated by their emotional (right) brain. Connecting emotionally helps them feel understood, making them more receptive to guidance from your logical (left) brain.
When a child is upset about leaving the park, first acknowledge their feelings ('I see you're sad to leave'), then redirect ('Let's think about what fun thing we can do at home').

content: Pause and empathize before offering solutions.
Use a calm tone and gentle touch to connect.
After connecting, offer simple, clear guidance.

title: Name It to Tame It
summary: Help children process big feelings by telling the story and naming emotions.

details.content: Naming emotions and narrating experiences helps integrate the left and right brain, making overwhelming feelings more manageable.
If a child is scared after a nightmare, help them talk through what happened and label their feelings ('You felt scared because the dream was so real').

content: Encourage your child to describe what happened.
Help them identify and name their feelings.
Reassure them that it's okay to have big emotions.

title: Engage, Don't Enrage
summary: Appeal to the logical brain to avoid triggering emotional outbursts.

details.content: When children feel threatened or misunderstood, their emotional (downstairs) brain takes over, leading to meltdowns. Engaging the logical (upstairs) brain helps them think and respond calmly.
Instead of demanding compliance ('Do it now!'), ask for your child's input or offer choices ('Would you like to brush your teeth before or after pajamas?').

content: Use curiosity and questions instead of commands.
Offer limited choices to give a sense of control.
Stay calm and avoid power struggles.

title: Use It or Lose It
summary: Encourage children to practice using their upstairs (thinking) brain.

details.content: The more children use skills like planning, decision-making, and self-control, the stronger these brain pathways become.
Let your child help plan a family outing, make a grocery list, or solve a simple problem together.

content: Ask your child to think through solutions to everyday problems.
Encourage reflection on past experiences.
Praise efforts to use self-control and make good decisions.

title: Move It or Lose It
summary: Use physical movement to help shift emotional states.

details.content: Movement can help regulate emotions by changing the body's chemistry and activating different brain areas.
If your child is upset, suggest jumping, dancing, or taking a walk together to help them calm down.

content: Encourage movement breaks during stressful moments.
Make physical activity a regular part of your routine.
Model using movement to manage your own emotions.

title: Let the Clouds of Emotion Roll By
summary: Teach children that feelings are temporary and will pass.

details.content: Understanding that emotions are like passing clouds helps children avoid getting stuck in negative feelings.
When your child is angry or sad, remind them that these feelings will pass, just like clouds moving across the sky.

content: Use imagery (clouds, waves) to describe emotions.
Model patience and acceptance of your own feelings.
Encourage your child to notice and name their changing emotions.

title: SIFT: Sensations, Images, Feelings, Thoughts
summary: Help children become aware of their inner experiences using the SIFT framework.

details.content: Awareness of sensations, images, feelings, and thoughts helps children understand themselves and respond more thoughtfully.
Ask your child to describe what their body feels, what pictures pop into their mind, what emotions they're having, and what thoughts are running through their head.

content: Guide your child through the SIFT process during calm moments.
Use open-ended questions to explore each area.
Practice SIFT together regularly to build self-awareness.
